ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Two recorded lectures, one optional live virtual lecture
recorded lecture, live virtual lecture, and live virtual discussion section
two virtual lectures, one live virtual lecture, one seminar
live virtual lecture, virtual discussion section
Recorded lecture with one  live discussion section and lecture a week
Live 30-minute lecture every week, plus 2 recorded lectures and 1 live discussion section
Recorded lectures, live lectures, and virtual discussion sections.
synchronous lecture and synchronous section
Recorded lecture, virtual seminar
Live virtual lectures and discussion sections offered once a week
Live lecture and section

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Read more contemporary poetry and developed an understanding for poet motivations/use of poetic techniques
was exposed to many poets since 1950 I had never read before; learned about how to read with and without a biographical lens; learned about trends in English poetry
knowledge on poetry across mutlitple poets

This course truly improved my ability to read deeply into contemporary poetry. It was already my favorite kind of poetry, but this class somehow made me love it even more. I think part of that is because of how it's organized around poets rather than particular themes; "getting to know" the poets was so interesting and surprisingly helpful in tapping into the layers of their poetry.
A general understanding of the trajectory of English-language poetry since 1950 and a general idea of how to write an English paper.
I learned to read poetry. I had no idea how to approach a poem before this semester and I fell in love with the process.

Knowledge of seminal English poetry after 1950s, in America, Britain, and around the world; skills for close textual analysis, such as identifying poetic form, sound patterns, rhetorical devices, and synthesizing motifs and themes.

I learned to interact with poetry as a whole and find common themes among many poets in the modern era. This was the first opetry class I have taken, and it would have been helpful to take a more introductory course earlier to have a base level of knowledge.
I learned to speak and write about poetry, and to have confidence in the validity of my ideas about it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Papers are interesting to write and consider
no weaknesses, an incredible course!

one strength is that all of the TFs and Prof are super engaged and willing to help students and honestly make the class wonderful

a weakness was there wasn't always much student engagement in section (though for that students are more to blame than the course) and sometimes the lectures were longer than the allotted time.

Its a good overview of modern poetry but sometimes I felt like there wasnt adequate instruction on how to analyze poetry. Instead, we were just told to read poems and figure it out as we go based on Prof Hammers analysis
Strengths: Discussion section was very well organized and prepared for by TF

I think the availability of the professor and the teaching fellows was a strength of the course, but I think a little more direction in the weekly readings could have made it easier to be better prepared for discussion. We would often read a wide range of material, but not end up discussing the majority of it.

I think, as far as an online course goes, this course perfectly executed the format. The content was engaging and steady, but didn't require a huge amount of interpersonal discussion to understand. The recorded lectures allowed me to connect with the readings in a new way each week. This structure felt really important for readings that at times can be difficult to access. I don't really have weaknesses for this class. I think it worked.

Strength: Prof Langdon Hammer, whose informed and nuanced interpretations of poetry have inspired a keener sensibility in me. The course also strikes a  good balance between Ame, Brit & world poetry and draws interesting thematic connections between various poets and their creative contexts. Weakness: Weekly reading assignments could be more directed, e.g. with specific questions given beforehand, to inform section discussions.

The recorded lectures were a bit of a struggle for me, though it helped that they were on the shorter side. My biggest complaint is that we only went over maybe four or five of the fifteen to twenty poems that we read before every lecture. However, the small sections were an awesome way to go in depth, and Professor Hammer is fantastic in lecture and in office hours.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Asynchronous lectures were very convenient
highly successful; enjoyed writing reading responses in email form directly to the instructor
I liked the system of having asynchronous lectures and then a live one. It was really helpful

I actually really loved Prof. Hammer's recorded lectures. Being able to pause/slow down/speed up as needed allowed me to take more thorough notes, which I've even consulted for papers in other poetry classes. Something I didn't realize at first would be a godsend was the lack of discussion posts! Instead of requiring students to come up with something ~super smart~ that everyone will read on Canvas, Prof. Hammer asked us to send him a weekly email about basically anythingquestions, thoughts, confusion, "even an emoji," as he told usand no one was penalized for missing a week or two. This took the pressure off, allowing me to ask/say things I was really interested in/curious about without feeling the need to sound "academic," so to speak, especially when there are so many other things to deal with right now that are more important than discussion posts.

I thought it was useful that we had small discussion sections, albeit over zoom. I think it can be difficult to pay attention to recorded lectures, though, so perhaps making one of the recorded ones into a live lecture would be useful.
See above.

The weekly live virtual lecture could perhaps be made more interactive by a more structured format, e.g. we could start the session with a reading/recital/performance, then take a previously released prompt as a starting point for discussion.
The recorded lectures would have been better for me if they had been live (or at least 2 live 1 recorded). The sections were really helpful and my TA Audrey was awesome.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you would like to read and discuss beautiful poetry

Yes. One of the best courses I have taken at Yale. Incredible for someone who is very interested in and already familiar with English poetry and also for someone who does not have much poetry experience

YES!!!! TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Even if you don't know the first thing about poetry, this class is designed to give students the most concrete entry points as possible into reading contemporary poetry. There were tons of really helpful handouts (which I downloaded and will definitely be using in both personal and academic future pursuits). Prof. Hammer and the TFs will get you excited about contemporary poetry and make you feel comfortable tossing around ideas and questions in discussion.
Yes, its a good way to read poetry with no background needed
I would if you have a strong interest in poetry, but not if you are simply looking to fulfill a writing credit.
Absolutely. I think it accomplishes a rare feat for introductory courses: it introduces you to the material without being overly simplistic about it.
Yes, especially if you're looking for an accessible yet substantial introduction to reading poetry
In a normal year I think this would be a fun and engaging course, and would definitely recommend to any student interested in modern poetry.
Yes! It's an accessible and enjoyable survey of good poetry with a very manageable workload. What's not to love?
